252.question: Which other approaches do they compare their model with?

6-Table3-1.png: They compare their model with the Akbik et al. (2018) and Link et al. (2012) approaches.

252.answer: Akbik et al. (2018), Link et al. (2012)

253.question: Which other approaches do they compare their model with?

6-Table3-1.png: They compare their model with the Akbik et al. (2018) and Link et al. (2012) approaches.

253.answer: They compare to Akbik et al. (2018) and Link et al. (2012).

254.question: What results do they achieve using their proposed approach?

5-Figure3-1.png: The image does not provide specific information about the results achieved using their proposed approach.
5-Table2-1.png: The table shows the performance of a model from the NER classifier evaluated on OntoNotes and the 112 subclass Wikidata linking step evaluated on Wiki(GOLD). The results are presented in terms of precision, recall, and F-1 scores for each category. The first column denotes the percentage breakdown per class type. All values are rounded to the nearest whole number. Since the table only shows 7 categories, the percentages will not sum to 100.

254.answer: F-1 score on the OntoNotes is 88%, and it is 53% on Wiki (gold).

256.question: How do they combine a deep learning model with a knowledge base?

4-Figure2-1.png: The deep learning model, specifically the ELMo token embeddings, is combined with a knowledge base by passing the detected entities from the model into the knowledge base. In this case, the knowledge base used is Wikidata. This integration allows for more accurate and contextually relevant information to be provided in response to user queries.

256.answer: Entities from a deep learning model are linked to the related entities from a knowledge base by a lookup.
